sentences.text: The deal has received condemnation and opposition from Somalia, Eritrea and Egypt, with Somalia recalling its ambassador to Ethiopia in protest. Somalia previously demanded Ethiopia make a public withdrawal from the MoU before the two countries could engage in any dialogue. The dispute has also put Ethiopian participation in the new African Union Support and Stabilization Mission in Somalia (AUSSOM) in question.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |last=Mutambo |first=Aggrey |date=2024-10-27 |title=Somalia dilemma in funding next peace mission, Ethiopia fallout |url=https://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/tea/news/east-africa/somalia-dilemma-in-funding-next-peace-mission-ethiopia-fallout-4802720 |url-access=subscription |access-date=2024-12-28 |website=The EastAfrican |language=en |quote=Mogadishu has insisted any dialogue can only go forth if Addis Ababa publicly withdraws from the MoU and some experts say Ethiopia should rethink the deal, or redo the MoU through Mogadishu.}}</ref>

sentences.text: Following talks brokered by Ethiopiaâ€“Turkey relations|Turkey, on 12 December 2024, Ethiopia and Somalia signed '''Ankara Declaration''' agreed to end their dispute over Ethiopia's plan to build a port in Somaliland. Notably the agreement made no mention of the MoU, Ethiopia has not confirmed its cancellation and Somaliland maintains the agreement stands.

references.text: <ref name="BBC ET SOM TR">{{Cite web |last=Yibeltal |first=Kalkidan |last2=Rukanga |first2=Basillioh |last3=Dahir |first3=Bidhaan |date=2024-12-12 |title=Ethiopia and Somalia agree to end bitter Somaliland port feud |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cvgr7v1evvgo |access-date=2024-12-18 |website=BBC News}}</ref>

<ref name="AJ ET SOM TR">{{Cite web |date=2024-12-12 |title=Somalia, Ethiopia agree on compromise to end tension, Turkish leader says |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/12/12/somalia-ethiopia-agree-on-compromise-to-end-tension-turkish-leader-says |access-date=2024-12-18 |website=Al Jazeera}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |title=Ethiopia and Somalia claim to have settled a dangerous feud |url=https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2024/12/19/ethiopia-and-somalia-claim-to-have-settled-a-dangerous-feud |access-date=2024-12-28 |work=The Economist |issn=0013-0613 |quote=The vaguely worded declaration does not mention the MOU and Ethiopia has not confirmed it has cancelled it. Somaliland, the other party to the MOU, has greeted the news from Ankara with a shrug. Senior Somaliland officials say they have heard nothing from Ethiopia to suggest that the deal is off the table.}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 1 January 2024, Ethiopia signed memorandum of understanding (MoU) with Somaliland in order to acquire access the Red Sea port. The text of the MoU was not released. President of Somaliland Muse Bihi Abdi stated that it included the lease of more than 19 kilometres of sea access around Berbera for 50 years to the Ethiopian Navy. It was also stated that the MoU included a provision for the future recognition by Ethiopia of Somaliland as a sovereign state.

references.text: <ref name="bbc20240101">{{Cite news |date=2024-01-01 |title=Ethiopia signs agreement with Somaliland paving way to sea access |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-67858566 |access-date=2024-01-03 |work=BBC News |language=en-GB |archive-date=2024-01-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240102230849/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-67858566 |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Abdi said the agreement would lead Ethiopia to set "a precedent as the first nation to extend international recognition to our country". Ethiopian politician Redwan Hussein stated that the MoU also included Somaliland taking a stake in Ethiopian Airlines. The MoU is not a legally binding agreement, which would require ratification by both parties.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=3 January 2024 |title=Why a Port Deal Has the Horn of Africa on Edge |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/01/02/world/africa/ethiopia-somaliland-port-deal.html |website=The New York Times |access-date=3 January 2024 |archive-date=17 August 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240817184226/https://www.nytimes.com/2024/01/02/world/africa/ethiopia-somaliland-port-deal.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: The Cabinet of Somalia held an emergency meeting on 2 January following the announcement of the MoU.

references.text: <ref name="bbc20240101" /> Somali President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud expressed his firm opposition to the agreement, saying Somaliland is part of Somalia under its constitution and the deal was conducted without legal basis with disdaining the rule of the United Nations|UN, African Union|AU, and IGAD.{{Citation needed|date=January 2024}} He also added "Somaliland, you are the northern regions of Somalia and Ethiopia has no recognition for you. If Ethiopia claimed it gave you recognition, then it is not a recognition that exists."<ref name="reuters20240102">{{Cite web |date=3 January 2024 |title=Somalia rejects port deal between Ethiopia and Somaliland |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/somalias-cabinet-calls-emergency-meet-ethiopia-somaliland-port-deal-2024-01-02/ |website=Reuters}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 3 January, Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi held a telephone call with the Somali president, stating "Egypt will maintain a firm position alongside Somalia and support its security and stability".  Mogadishu recalled its ambassador to Ethiopia.  Somaliland Interior Minister Mohamed Kahin Ahmed|Mohamed Kahin told reporters on 2 January that "We ask Somalia to apologize for its claim that Somaliland is part of Somalia"<ref name="reuters20240102" />

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-01-03 |title=Egypt stands firm with Somalia in face-off against Ethiopia |url=https://www.africanews.com/2024/01/03/egypt-stands-firm-with-somalia-in-face-off-against-ethiopia/ |access-date=2024-01-03 |website=Africanews |language=en |archive-date=2024-08-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240817184228/https://www.africanews.com/2024/01/03/egypt-stands-firm-with-somalia-in-face-off-against-ethiopia/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-01-03 |title=Somalia lashes out at Ethiopia-Somaliland port deal |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/1/2/somalias-cabinet-calls-emergency-meet-on-ethiopia-somaliland-port-deal |access-date=2024-01-03 |website=Al Jazeera Media Network|Al Jazeera |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: At a press conference on 11 January, Ministry of Foreign Affairs of China spokesperson Mao Ning (diplomat)|Mao Ning stated that China "supports countries in safeguarding sovereignty and territorial integrity" and that "Somaliland is part of Somalia." She also said that issue must be handled through diplomatic dialogue and "achieve common development by having friendly cooperation."

references.text: <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/china-backs-somalia-in-row-with-ethiopia-about-port-deal/3106463|title=China backs Somalia in row with Ethiopia about port deal|first=Riyaz|last=ul Khaliq|newspaper=Andolu Ajansi|date=2024-01-11|access-date=2024-01-31|archive-date=2024-08-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240817184253/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/china-backs-somalia-in-row-with-ethiopia-about-port-deal/3106463|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: In the wake of agreement on 3 January, the Mogadishu administration organized a rally to express opposition to the deal. Many Somali protestors chanted and held banners to express their uncertainty of the lease agreement that perceived to endanger Somalia's territory. In the rally, Somalia's Interior Minister Ahmed Moalim Fiqi|Ahmed Moallim Fiqi attended to the scene who said to protestors, "the federal government finds it unacceptable that we're ignored by an Ethiopian prime minister who belittles our federal government's role by delegitimizing it. That's a violation and unacceptable."
